description: From Latin percussus, past participle of percutiō (“strike, beat”), from per (“through”) + quatiō (“shake, strike”).

verbs.description: percuss (third-person singular simple present percusses, present participle percussing, simple past and past participle percussed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to strike; to hit; to knock; to give a blow to
examples: Solid bodies, if they be very softly percussed, give no sound.
Falling on the roof of the caravan, the hailstones percussed noisily.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly medicine) to attempt to divine the location or other quality of something by tapping on (an overlying surface)
examples: The doctor percussed his chest to determine whether he had pneumonia.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly medicine) to attempt to divine the location or other quality of (something) by tapping on an overlying surface
examples: Percussing a patient's spleen is best done while he is on his back.
